value: File:Narbonne Cathedrale Saint Just et Saint Pasteur.jpg
The Cathedrale Saint Just et Saint Pasteur

Narbonne was an important place in Roman times, being at the junction between the Via Domitia and the Via Aquitania. Trade was prominent here and there was a Forum and warehouses for grain and products. The underground storage sites are worth visiting.
Narbonne has an SNCF rail station with direct connections to

and many regional destinations.

The A9 (Route Aquitaine) and A61 motorways pass through/near Narbonne.

The nearest airport is in
, and other (relatively) close airports are in
Much of the city centre can be covered on foot. There is also a free (tiny!) shuttle bus that cuts a route from the Mediatheque along the canal and around other parts of town.

value: The Archbishops Palace on the main square in town.
content=Good views from the top of the tower (donjon) over towards the nearby cathedral and the surrounding areas.
content=An excavated section of the Via Domitia, the Roman road that ran from Italy to Spain.
content=Begun in 1272, but unfinished, this cathedral is the fourth tallest in France.
content=An archaeological museum in the town centre
content=A former grain warehouse, built underground as a cryptoporticus.

There are various cafes and bars around the main square.
, soak up some rays on the beach
, or head down to Catalonian city
